215 /*
216 Used to avoid scanning full tables on an index. If this flag is set then

226 /*
227 Can the storage engine handle spatial data.
228 Used to check that no spatial attributes are declared unless
229 the storage engine is capable of handling it.
230 */
231 #define HA_CAN_GEOMETRY (1 << 4)
232 /*
233 Reading keys in random order is as fast as reading keys in sort order
234 (Used by filesort to decide if we should sort key + data or key +
235 pointer-to-row.)
236 */
237 #define HA_FAST_KEY_READ (1 << 5)
238 /*
239 Set the following flag if we on delete should force all key to be read

244 Is NULL values allowed in indexes.

249 /*
250 Tells that we can the position for the conflicting duplicate key
251 record is stored in table->file->dupp_ref. (insert uses rnd_pos() on
252 this to find the duplicated row)

254 #define HA_DUPLICATE_POS (1 << 8)
255 #define HA_NO_BLOBS (1 << 9) /* Doesn't support blobs */
256 /*
257 Is the storage engine capable of defining an index of a prefix on
258 a BLOB attribute.
259 */
260 #define HA_CAN_INDEX_BLOBS (1 << 10)
261 /*
262 Auto increment fields can be part of a multi-part key. For second part
263 auto-increment keys, the auto_incrementing is done in handler.cc
264 */
265 #define HA_AUTO_PART_KEY (1 << 11)
266 /*
267 Can't define a table without primary key (and cannot handle a table
268 with hidden primary key)
269 */
270 #define HA_REQUIRE_PRIMARY_KEY (1 << 12)
271 /*
272 Does the counter of records after the info call specify an exact
273 value or not. If it does this flag is set.
274 */
275 #define HA_STATS_RECORDS_IS_EXACT (1 << 13)
276 /// Not in use.
277 #define HA_UNUSED14 (1 << 14)
278 /*
279 This parameter is set when the handler will also return the primary key
280 when doing read-only-key on another index, i.e., if we get the primary
281 key columns for free when we do an index read (usually, it also implies
282 that HA_PRIMARY_KEY_REQUIRED_FOR_POSITION flag is set).
283 */
284 #define HA_PRIMARY_KEY_IN_READ_INDEX (1 << 15)
285 /*
286 If HA_PRIMARY_KEY_REQUIRED_FOR_POSITION is set, it means that to position()
287 uses a primary key given by the record argument.
288 Without primary key, we can't call position().
289 If not set, the position is returned as the current rows position
290 regardless of what argument is given.
291 */
292 #define HA_PRIMARY_KEY_REQUIRED_FOR_POSITION (1 << 16)
293 #define HA_CAN_RTREEKEYS (1 << 17)
294 /// Not in use.
295 #define HA_UNUSED18
296 /*
297 The following is we need to a primary key to delete (and update) a row.
298 If there is no primary key, all columns needs to be read on update and delete
299 */
300 #define HA_PRIMARY_KEY_REQUIRED_FOR_DELETE (1 << 19)
301 /*
302 Indexes on prefixes of character fields are not allowed.
303 */
304 #define HA_NO_PREFIX_CHAR_KEYS (1 << 20)
305 /*
306 Does the storage engine support fulltext indexes.

308 #define HA_CAN_FULLTEXT (1 << 21)
309 /*
310 Can the HANDLER interface in the MySQL API be used towards this
311 storage engine.
312 */
313 #define HA_CAN_SQL_HANDLER (1 << 22)
314 /*
315 Set if the storage engine does not support auto increment fields.
316 */
317 #define HA_NO_AUTO_INCREMENT (1 << 23)
318 /*
319 Supports CHECKSUM option in CREATE TABLE (MyISAM feature).
320 */
321 #define HA_HAS_CHECKSUM (1 << 24)
322 /*
323 Table data are stored in separate files (for lower_case_table_names).
324 Should file names always be in lower case (used by engines that map
325 table names to file names.
326 */
327 #define HA_FILE_BASED (1 << 26)
328 #define HA_NO_VARCHAR (1 << 27)
329 /*
330 Is the storage engine capable of handling bit fields.
331 */
332 #define HA_CAN_BIT_FIELD (1 << 28)
333 #define HA_ANY_INDEX_MAY_BE_UNIQUE (1 << 30)
334 #define HA_NO_COPY_ON_ALTER (1LL << 31)
335 #define HA_COUNT_ROWS_INSTANT (1LL << 32) /* records() gives exact count*/
336 /* Has it's own method of binlog logging */
337 #define HA_HAS_OWN_BINLOGGING (1LL << 33)
338 /*
339 Engine is capable of row-format and statement-format logging,
340 respectively
341 */
342 #define HA_BINLOG_ROW_CAPABLE (1LL << 34)
343 #define HA_BINLOG_STMT_CAPABLE (1LL << 35)
344 /*
345 When a multiple key conflict happens in a REPLACE command mysql
346 expects the conflicts to be reported in the ascending order of
347 key names.
348
349 For e.g.
350
351 CREATE TABLE t1 (a INT, UNIQUE (a), b INT NOT NULL, UNIQUE (b), c INT NOT
352 NULL, INDEX(c));
353
354 REPLACE INTO t1 VALUES (1,1,1),(2,2,2),(2,1,3);
355
356 MySQL expects the conflict with 'a' to be reported before the conflict with
357 'b'.
358
359 If the underlying storage engine does not report the conflicting keys in
360 ascending order, it causes unexpected errors when the REPLACE command is
361 executed.
362
363 This flag helps the underlying SE to inform the server that the keys are not
364 ordered.
365 */
366 #define HA_DUPLICATE_KEY_NOT_IN_ORDER (1LL << 36)
367 /*
368 Engine supports REPAIR TABLE. Used by CHECK TABLE FOR UPGRADE if an
369 incompatible table is detected. If this flag is set, CHECK TABLE FOR UPGRADE
370 will report ER_TABLE_NEEDS_UPGRADE, otherwise ER_TABLE_NEED_REBUILD.
371 */
372 #define HA_CAN_REPAIR (1LL << 37)
373
374 /*
375 Set of all binlog flags. Currently only contain the capabilities
376 flags.
377 */
378 #define HA_BINLOG_FLAGS (HA_BINLOG_ROW_CAPABLE | HA_BINLOG_STMT_CAPABLE)
379
380 /**
381 The handler supports read before write removal optimization
382
383 Read before write removal may be used for storage engines which support
384 write without previous read of the row to be updated. Handler returning
385 this flag must implement start_read_removal() and end_read_removal().
386 The handler may return "fake" rows constructed from the key of the row
387 asked for. This is used to optimize UPDATE and DELETE by reducing the
388 number of round-trips between handler and storage engine.
389
390 Example:
391 UPDATE a=1 WHERE pk IN (@<keys@>)
392
393 @verbatim
394 mysql_update()
395 {
396 if (<conditions for starting read removal>)
397 start_read_removal()
398 -> handler returns true if read removal supported for this table/query
399
400 while(read_record("pk=<key>"))
401 -> handler returns fake row with column "pk" set to <key>
402
403 ha_update_row()
404 -> handler sends write "a=1" for row with "pk=<key>"
405
406 end_read_removal()
407 -> handler returns the number of rows actually written
408 }
409 @endverbatim
410
411 @note This optimization in combination with batching may be used to
412 remove even more round-trips.
413 */
414 #define HA_READ_BEFORE_WRITE_REMOVAL (1LL << 38)
415
416 /*
417 Engine supports extended fulltext API
418 */
419 #define HA_CAN_FULLTEXT_EXT (1LL << 39)
420
421 /*
422 Storage engine doesn't synchronize result set with expected table contents.
423 Used by replication slave to check if it is possible to retrieve rows from
424 the table when deciding whether to do a full table scan, index scan or hash
425 scan while applying a row event.
426 */
427 #define HA_READ_OUT_OF_SYNC (1LL << 40)
428
429 /*
430 Storage engine supports table export using the
431 FLUSH TABLE <table_list> FOR EXPORT statement.
432 */
433 #define HA_CAN_EXPORT (1LL << 41)
434
435 /*
436 The handler don't want accesses to this table to
437 be const-table optimized

439 #define HA_BLOCK_CONST_TABLE (1LL << 42)
440
441 /*
442 Handler supports FULLTEXT hints

444 #define HA_CAN_FULLTEXT_HINTS (1LL << 43)

446 /**
447 Storage engine doesn't support LOCK TABLE ... READ LOCAL locks
448 but doesn't want to use handler::store_lock() API for upgrading
449 them to LOCK TABLE ... READ locks, for example, because it doesn't
450 use THR_LOCK locks at all.
451 */
452 #define HA_NO_READ_LOCAL_LOCK (1LL << 44)
453
454 /**
455 A storage engine is compatible with the attachable transaction requirements
456 means that
457
458 - either SE detects the fact that THD::ha_data was reset and starts a new
459 attachable transaction, closes attachable transaction on close_connection
460 and resumes regular (outer) transaction when THD::ha_data is restored;
461
462 - or SE completely ignores THD::ha_data and close_connection like MyISAM
463 does.
464 */
465 #define HA_ATTACHABLE_TRX_COMPATIBLE (1LL << 45)

488 If this isn't defined, only columns/indexes with Cartesian coordinate systems

492 #define HA_SUPPORTS_GEOGRAPHIC_GEOMETRY_COLUMN (1LL << 50)
493
494 /**

513 #define HA_NO_INDEX_ACCESS (1LL << 54)

516 Supports multi-valued index

520 There is no need to evict the table from the table definition cache having run

525 /*
526 Bits in index_flags(index_number) for what you can do with index.
527 If you do not implement indexes, just return zero here.
528 */
529 /*
530 Does the index support read next, this is assumed in the server
531 code and never checked so all indexes must support this.
532 Note that the handler can be used even if it doesn't have any index.
533 */
534 #define HA_READ_NEXT 1 /* TODO really use this flag */
535 /*
536 Can the index be used to scan backwards (supports ::index_prev).
537 */
538 #define HA_READ_PREV 2
539 /*
540 Can the index deliver its record in index order. Typically true for
541 all ordered indexes and not true for hash indexes. Used to set keymap
542 part_of_sortkey.
543 This keymap is only used to find indexes usable for resolving an ORDER BY
544 in the query. Thus in most cases index_read will work just fine without
545 order in result production. When this flag is set it is however safe to
546 order all output started by index_read since most engines do this. With
547 read_multi_range calls there is a specific flag setting order or not
548 order so in those cases ordering of index output can be avoided.
549 */
550 #define HA_READ_ORDER 4
551 /*
552 Specify whether index can handle ranges, typically true for all
553 ordered indexes and not true for hash indexes.
554 Used by optimiser to check if ranges (as key >= 5) can be optimised
555 by index.
556 */
557 #define HA_READ_RANGE 8
558 /*
559 Can't use part key searches. This is typically true for hash indexes
560 and typically not true for ordered indexes.
561 */
562 #define HA_ONLY_WHOLE_INDEX 16
563 /*
564 Index does not store NULL values, even if the column is nullable.
565 (KEY::flags may still contain HA_NULL_PART_KEY)
566 If the key has a NULL-value, the handler need to do a full table scan
567 instead of using this key. This is typically true for NDB hash indexes.
568 */
569 #define HA_TABLE_SCAN_ON_NULL 32
570 /*
571 Does the storage engine support index-only scans on this index.
572 Enables use of HA_EXTRA_KEYREAD and HA_EXTRA_NO_KEYREAD
573 Used to set Key_map keys_for_keyread and to check in optimiser for
574 index-only scans. When doing a read under HA_EXTRA_KEYREAD the handler
575 only have to fill in the columns the key covers. If
576 HA_PRIMARY_KEY_IN_READ_INDEX is set then also the PRIMARY KEY columns
577 must be updated in the row.
578 */
579 #define HA_KEYREAD_ONLY 64
580 /*
581 Index scan will not return records in rowid order. Not guaranteed to be
582 set for unordered (e.g. HASH) indexes.
583 */
584 #define HA_KEY_SCAN_NOT_ROR 128

628 /**
629 Options for the START TRANSACTION statement.
630
631 Note that READ ONLY and READ WRITE are logically mutually exclusive.
632 This is enforced by the parser and depended upon by trans_begin().
633
634 We need two flags instead of one in order to differentiate between
635 situation when no READ WRITE/ONLY clause were given and thus transaction
636 is implicitly READ WRITE and the case when READ WRITE clause was used
637 explicitly.
638 */
639
640 // WITH CONSISTENT SNAPSHOT option
641 static const uint MYSQL_START_TRANS_OPT_WITH_CONS_SNAPSHOT = 1;
642 // READ ONLY option
643 static const uint MYSQL_START_TRANS_OPT_READ_ONLY = 2;
644 // READ WRITE option
645 static const uint MYSQL_START_TRANS_OPT_READ_WRITE = 4;
646 // HIGH PRIORITY option
647 static const uint MYSQL_START_TRANS_OPT_HIGH_PRIORITY = 8;

1244 typedef ulonglong my_xid; // this line is the same as in log_event.h
1245 /**
1246 Enumeration of possible states for externally coordinated transactions (XA).
1247 */
1248 enum class enum_ha_recover_xa_state : int {
1249 NOT_FOUND = -1, // Trnasaction not found
1250 PREPARED_IN_SE = 0, // Transaction is prepared in SEs
1251 PREPARED_IN_TC = 1, // Transaction is prepared in SEs and TC
1252 COMMITTED_WITH_ONEPHASE = 2, // Transaction was one-phase committed
1253 COMMITTED = 3, // Transaction was committed
1254 ROLLEDBACK = 4 // Transaction was rolled back
1255 };
1256 /**
1257 Single occurrence set of XIDs of internally coordinated transactions
1258 found as been committed in the transaction coordinator state.
1259 */
1260 using Xid_commit_list =
1261 std::unordered_set<my_xid, std::hash<my_xid>, std::equal_to<my_xid>,
1262 Mem_root_allocator<my_xid>>;
1263
1264 /**
1265 Class to maintain list of externally coordinated transactions and their
1266 current state at recovery.
1267 */
1268 class Xa_state_list {
1269 public:
1270 using pair = std::pair<const XID, enum_ha_recover_xa_state>;
1271 using allocator = Mem_root_allocator<Xa_state_list::pair>;
1272 using list = std::map<XID, enum_ha_recover_xa_state, std::less<XID>,
1273 Xa_state_list::allocator>;
1274 using iterator = std::map<XID, enum_ha_recover_xa_state, std::less<XID>,
1275 Xa_state_list::allocator>::iterator;
1276 using instantiation_tuple = std::tuple<
1277 std::unique_ptr<MEM_ROOT>, std::unique_ptr<Xa_state_list::allocator>,
1278 std::unique_ptr<Xa_state_list::list>, std::unique_ptr<Xa_state_list>>;
1279
1280 /**
1281 Class constructor.
1282
1283 @param populated_by_tc The underlying list of XIDs and transaction
1284 states, after being populated by the transaction
1285 coodinator.
1286 */
1287 Xa_state_list(Xa_state_list::list &populated_by_tc);
1288 34610 virtual ~Xa_state_list() = default;
1289
1290 /**
1291 Searches the underlying map to find an key that corresponds to the
1292 parameter.
1293
1294 @param to_find The XID to find within the underlying map.
1295
1296 @return Ha_recover_states::NOT_FOUND if the transaction wasn't found,
1297 the state of the transaction, otherwise.
1298 */
1299 enum_ha_recover_xa_state find(XID const &to_find);
1300 /**
1301 Adds a transaction and state to the underlying map. If the given XID
1302 already exists in the underlying map, the associated state changes according
1303 to the following rules:
1304
1305 - If the parameter state is `PREPARED_IN_SE` it means that the
1306 transaction didn't reach PREPARED_IN_TC, COMMIT or ROLLBACK for
1307 sure. In that case:
1308 . If other participants state is `COMMITTED`/`ROLLEDBACK`, it would
1309 mean that it's a state inherited from a previous execution with the
1310 same XID and we should set the state to `PREPARED_IN_SE`.
1311 . If other participants state is `PREPARED_IN_TC`/
1312 `COMMITTED_WITH_ONEPHASE` it means that the current participant
1313 didn't reach it but some other did so, keep the state as
1314 `PREPARED_IN_TC`/`COMMITTED_WITH_ONEPHASE`.
1315
1316 - If the parameter state is `PREPARED_IN_TC`, it means that other
1317 participants must have persisted either the PREPARE, the COMMIT or
1318 the ROLLBACK. In that case, keep whatever state is already there and
1319 ensure that is not `PREPARED_IN_SE`.
1320
1321 - If the parameter state is `COMMITTED_WITH_ONEPHASE`, `COMMITTED` or
1322 `ROLLEDBACK`, do nothing, only the active transaction coordinator has
1323 the ability, for now, to set the transaction state to those values.
1324
1325 @param xid The XID to be added (the key).
1326 @param xid The state to be added (the value).
1327
1328 @return The current value of the transaction state if the XID has
1329 already been added, Ha_recover_states::NOT_FOUND otherwise.
1330 */
1331 enum_ha_recover_xa_state add(XID const &xid, enum_ha_recover_xa_state state);
1332 /**
1333 Factory like method to instantiate all the infra-structure needed to
1334 create an `Xa_state_list`. Since such infra-structuer is dependent on
1335 `MEM_ROOT` and `Mem_root_allocator`, the method returns a tuple
1336 containing unique pointers to all 4 objects needed: MEM_ROOT;
1337 Mem_root_allocator; Xa_state_list::list; Xa_state_list.
1338
1339 @return An std::tuple containing unique pointers to all 4 objects
1340 needed: MEM_ROOT; Mem_root_allocator; Xa_state_list::list;
1341 Xa_state_list.
1342 */
1343 static Xa_state_list::instantiation_tuple new_instance();
1344
1345 private:
1346 /** The underlying map holding the trx and states*/
1347 Xa_state_list::list &m_underlying;
1348 };

1425 /** X/Open XA distributed transaction status codes */
1426 enum xa_status_code {
1427 /**
1428 normal execution
1429 */
1430 XA_OK = 0,
1431
1432 /**
1433 asynchronous operation already outstanding
1434 */
1435 XAER_ASYNC = -2,
1436
1437 /**
1438 a resource manager error occurred in the transaction branch
1439 */
1440 XAER_RMERR = -3,
1441
1442 /**
1443 the XID is not valid
1444 */
1445 XAER_NOTA = -4,
1446
1447 /**
1448 invalid arguments were given
1449 */
1450 XAER_INVAL = -5,
1451
1452 /**
1453 routine invoked in an improper context
1454 */
1455 XAER_PROTO = -6,
1456
1457 /**
1458 resource manager unavailable
1459 */
1460 XAER_RMFAIL = -7,
1461
1462 /**
1463 the XID already exists
1464 */
1465 XAER_DUPID = -8,
1466
1467 /**
1468 resource manager doing work outside transaction
1469 */
1470 XAER_OUTSIDE = -9
1471 };

1760 Get the SDI keys in a tablespace into vector.

1762 @param[in,out] vector vector of SDI Keys

1765 */

1768
1769 /**
1770 Retrieve SDI for a given SDI key.
1771
1772 Since the caller of this api will not know the SDI length, SDI retrieval
1773 should be done in the following way.
1774
1775 i. Allocate initial memory of some size (Lets say 64KB)
1776 ii. Pass the allocated memory to the below api.
1777 iii. If passed buffer is sufficient, sdi_get_by_id() copies the sdi
1778 to the buffer passed and returns success, else sdi_len is modified
1779 with the actual length of the SDI (and returns false on failure).
1780 For genuine errors, sdi_len is returned as UINT64_MAX
1781 iv. If sdi_len != UINT64_MAX, retry the call after allocating the memory
1782 of sdi_len
1783 v. Free the memory after using SDI (responsibility of caller)
1784
1785 @param[in] tablespace tablespace object
1786 @param[in] sdi_key SDI key to uniquely identify SDI obj
1787 @param[in,out] sdi SDI retrieved from tablespace
1788 A non-null pointer must be passed in
1789 @param[in,out] sdi_len in: length of the memory allocated
1790 out: actual length of SDI
1791 @retval false success
1792 @retval true failure
1793 */
1794 typedef bool (*sdi_get_t)(const dd::Tablespace &tablespace,
1795 const sdi_key_t *sdi_key, void *sdi, uint64 *sdi_len);
1796
1797 /**
1798 Insert/Update SDI for a given SDI key.
1799 @param[in] hton handlerton object
1800 @param[in] tablespace tablespace object
1801 @param[in] table table object
1802 @param[in] sdi_key SDI key to uniquely identify SDI obj
1803 @param[in] sdi SDI to write into the tablespace
1804 @param[in] sdi_len length of SDI BLOB returned
1805 @retval false success
1806 @retval true failure, my_error() should be called
1807 by SE
1808 */
1809 typedef bool (*sdi_set_t)(handlerton *hton, const dd::Tablespace &tablespace,
1810 const dd::Table *table, const sdi_key_t *sdi_key,
1811 const void *sdi, uint64 sdi_len);
1812

1820 by SE

1849 /**
1850 Retrieve cost constants to be used for this storage engine.
1851
1852 A storage engine that wants to provide its own cost constants to
1853 be used in the optimizer cost model, should implement this function.
1854 The server will call this function to get a cost constant object
1855 that will be used for tables stored in this storage engine instead
1856 of using the default cost constants.
1857
1858 Life cycle for the cost constant object: The storage engine must
1859 allocate the cost constant object on the heap. After the function
1860 returns, the server takes over the ownership of this object.
1861 The server will eventually delete the object by calling delete.
1862
1863 @note In the initial version the storage_category parameter will
1864 not be used. The only valid value this will have is DEFAULT_STORAGE_CLASS
1865 (see declaration in opt_costconstants.h).
1866
1867 @param storage_category the storage type that the cost constants will
1868 be used for
1869
1870 @return a pointer to the cost constant object, if NULL is returned
1871 the default cost constants will be used
1872 */
1873 typedef SE_cost_constants *(*get_cost_constants_t)(uint storage_category);

1875 /**
1876 @param[in,out] thd pointer to THD
1877 @param[in] new_trx_arg pointer to replacement transaction
1878 @param[out] ptr_trx_arg double pointer to being replaced transaction
1879
1880 Associated with THD engine's native transaction is replaced
1881 with @c new_trx_arg. The old value is returned through a buffer if non-null
1882 pointer is provided with @c ptr_trx_arg.
1883 The method is adapted by XA start and XA prepare handlers to
1884 handle XA transaction that is logged as two parts by slave applier.
1885
1886 This interface concerns engines that are aware of XA transaction.
1887 */
1888 typedef void (*replace_native_transaction_in_thd_t)(THD *thd, void *new_trx_arg,
1889 void **ptr_trx_arg);

1997 /**
1998 Notify/get permission from storage engine before acquisition or after
1999 release of exclusive metadata lock on object represented by key.
2000
2001 @param thd Thread context.
2002 @param mdl_key MDL key identifying object on which exclusive
2003 lock is to be acquired/was released.
2004 @param notification_type Indicates whether this is pre-acquire or
2005 post-release notification.
2006 @param victimized 'true' if locking failed as we were selected
2007 as a victim in order to avoid possible deadlocks.
2008
2009 @note Notification is done only for objects from TABLESPACE, SCHEMA,
2010 TABLE, FUNCTION, PROCEDURE, TRIGGER and EVENT namespaces.
2011
2012 @note Problems during notification are to be reported as warnings, MDL
2013 subsystem will report generic error if pre-acquire notification
2014 fails/SE refuses lock acquisition.
2015 @note Return value is ignored/error is not reported in case of
2016 post-release notification.
2017
2018 @note In some cases post-release notification might happen even if
2019 there were no prior pre-acquire notification. For example,
2020 when SE was loaded after exclusive lock acquisition, or when
2021 we need notify SEs which permitted lock acquisition that it
2022 didn't happen because one of SEs didn't allow it (in such case
2023 we will do post-release notification for all SEs for simplicity).
2024
2025 @return False - if notification was successful/lock can be acquired,
2026 True - if it has failed/lock should not be acquired.
2027 */
2028 typedef bool (*notify_exclusive_mdl_t)(THD *thd, const MDL_key *mdl_key,
2029 ha_notification_type notification_type,
2030 bool *victimized);
2031
2032 /**
2033 Notify/get permission from storage engine before or after execution of
2034 ALTER TABLE operation on the table identified by the MDL key.
2035
2036 @param thd Thread context.
2037 @param mdl_key MDL key identifying table which is going to be
2038 or was ALTERed.
2039 @param notification_type Indicates whether this is pre-ALTER TABLE or
2040 post-ALTER TABLE notification.
2041
2042 @note This hook is necessary because for ALTER TABLE upgrade to X
2043 metadata lock happens fairly late during the execution process,
2044 so it can be expensive to abort ALTER TABLE operation at this
2045 stage by returning failure from notify_exclusive_mdl() hook.
2046
2047 @note This hook follows the same error reporting convention as
2048 @see notify_exclusive_mdl().
2049
2050 @note Similarly to notify_exclusive_mdl() in some cases post-ALTER
2051 notification might happen even if there were no prior pre-ALTER
2052 notification.
2053
2054 @note Post-ALTER notification can happen before post-release notification
2055 for exclusive metadata lock acquired by this ALTER TABLE.
2056
2057 @return False - if notification was successful/ALTER TABLE can proceed.
2058 True - if it has failed/ALTER TABLE should be aborted.
2059 */
2060 typedef bool (*notify_alter_table_t)(THD *thd, const MDL_key *mdl_key,
2061 ha_notification_type notification_type);

2352 /**
2353 Prepare the secondary engine for executing a statement. This function is
2354 called right after the secondary engine TABLE objects have been opened by
2355 open_secondary_engine_tables(), before the statement is optimized and
2356 executed. Secondary engines will typically create a context object in this
2357 function, which they can use to store state that is needed during the
2358 optimization and execution phases.
2359
2360 @param thd thread context
2361 @param lex the statement to execute
2362 @return true on error, false on success
2363 */
2364 using prepare_secondary_engine_t = bool (*)(THD *thd, LEX *lex);
2365
2366 /**
2367 Optimize a statement for execution on a secondary storage engine. This
2368 function is called when the optimization of a statement has completed, just
2369 before the statement is executed. Secondary engines can use this function to
2370 apply engine-specific optimizations to the execution plan. They can also
2371 reject executing the query by raising an error, in which case the query will
2372 be reprepared and executed by the primary storage engine.
2373
2374 @param thd thread context
2375 @param lex the statement being optimized
2376 @return true on error, false on success
2377 */
2378 using optimize_secondary_engine_t = bool (*)(THD *thd, LEX *lex);

2380 /**
2381 Compares the cost of two join plans in the secondary storage engine. The cost
2382 of the current candidate is compared with the cost of the best plan seen so
2383 far.
2384
2385 @param thd thread context
2386 @param join the candidate plan to evaluate
2387 @param optimizer_cost the cost estimate calculated by the optimizer
2388 @param[out] use_best_so_far true if the optimizer should stop searching for
2389 a better plan and use the best plan it has seen so far
2390 @param[out] cheaper true if the candidate is the best plan seen so far for
2391 this JOIN (must be true if it is the first plan seen),
2392 false otherwise
2393 @param[out] secondary_engine_cost the cost estimated by the secondary engine
2394
2395 @return false on success, or true if an error has been raised
2396 */
2397 using compare_secondary_engine_cost_t = bool (*)(THD *thd, const JOIN &join,
2398 double optimizer_cost,
2399 bool *use_best_so_far,
2400 bool *cheaper,
2401 double *secondary_engine_cost);
2402
2403 /**
2404 Evaluates the cost of executing the given access path in this secondary
2405 storage engine, and potentially modifies the cost estimates that are in the
2406 access path. This function is only called from the hypergraph join optimizer.
2407
2408 The function is called on every access path that the join optimizer might
2409 compare to an alternative access path. This includes both paths that represent
2410 complete execution plans and paths that represent partial plans. It is not
2411 guaranteed to be called on every child path. For example, if GROUP BY is done
2412 by sorting first and then aggregating the sorted results, the function will
2413 only be called on the aggregation path, and not on the sort path, because only
2414 the aggregation path will be compared to other paths.
2415
2416 The secondary engine is allowed to modify the estimates in the access path to
2417 better match the costs of the access path in the secondary engine. It can
2418 change any of the following AccessPath members:
2419
2420 - init_once_cost
2421 - init_cost
2422 - cost
2423 - cost_before_filter
2424 - num_output_rows
2425 - num_output_rows_before_filter
2426 - secondary_engine_data
2427
2428 Any other members should be left unchanged. The AccessPath must be in an
2429 internally consistent state when the function returns, and satisfy invariants
2430 expected by the hypergraph join optimizer, such as:
2431
2432 - init_cost <= cost_before_filter <= cost
2433 - num_output_rows <= num_output_rows_before_filter
2434
2435 The secondary engine can also reject an access path altogether, by returning
2436 true, in which case the join optimizer will not use that path in the final
2437 plan. Since the secondary engine can reject any partial or complete plan, it
2438 is possible that the join optimizer does not find any valid plan that is
2439 accepted. In this case, the join optimizer will raise an error.
2440
2441 If the secondary encounters an error when evaluating the cost of the path, it
2442 can signal an error by calling my_error() and return true, in which case the
2443 join optimizer will not suggest any plan for the query.
2444
2445 @param thd The thread context.
2446 @param hypergraph The hypergraph that represents the search space.
2447 @param[in,out] access_path The AccessPath to evaluate.
2448
2449 @retval false on success.
2450 @retval true if the plan is to be rejected, or if an error was raised.
2451 */
2452 using secondary_engine_modify_access_path_cost_t = bool (*)(
2453 THD *thd, const JoinHypergraph &hypergraph, AccessPath *access_path);
2454
2455 // Capabilities (bit flags) for secondary engines.
2456 using SecondaryEngineFlags = uint64_t;
2457 enum class SecondaryEngineFlag : SecondaryEngineFlags {
2458 SUPPORTS_HASH_JOIN = 0,
2459 SUPPORTS_NESTED_LOOP_JOIN = 1,
2460
2461 // If this flag is set, aggregation (GROUP BY and DISTINCT) do not require
2462 // ordered inputs and create unordered outputs. This is typically the case
2463 // if they are implemented using hash-based techniques.
2464 AGGREGATION_IS_UNORDERED = 2
2465 };
2466
2467 /// Creates an empty bitmap of access path types. This is the base
2468 /// case for the function template with the same name below.
2469 3955 inline constexpr SecondaryEngineFlags MakeSecondaryEngineFlags() { return 0; }
2470
2471 /// Creates a bitmap representing a set of access path types.
2472 template <typename... Args>
2473 9290 constexpr SecondaryEngineFlags MakeSecondaryEngineFlags(
2474 SecondaryEngineFlag flag1, Args... rest) {
2475 9290 return (uint64_t{1} << static_cast<int>(flag1)) |
2476 9290 MakeSecondaryEngineFlags(rest...);
2477 }

2596 /**
2597 handlerton is a singleton structure - one instance per storage engine -
2598 to provide access to storage engine functionality that works on the
2599 "global" level (unlike handler class that works on a per-table basis).
2600
2601 usually handlerton instance is defined statically in ha_xxx.cc as
2602
2603 static handlerton { ... } xxx_hton;
2604
2605 savepoint_*, prepare, recover, and *_by_xid pointers can be 0.
2606 */
2607 struct handlerton {
2608 /**
2609 Historical marker for if the engine is available or not.
2610 */
2611 SHOW_COMP_OPTION state;
2612
2613 /**
2614 Historical number used for frm file to determine the correct storage engine.
2615 This is going away and new engines will just use "name" for this.
2616 */
2617 enum legacy_db_type db_type;
2618 /**
2619 Each storage engine has it's own memory area (actually a pointer)
2620 in the thd, for storing per-connection information.
2621 It is accessed as
2622
2623 thd->ha_data[xxx_hton.slot]
2624
2625 slot number is initialized by MySQL after xxx_init() is called.
2626 */
2627 uint slot;
2628 /**
2629 To store per-savepoint data storage engine is provided with an area
2630 of a requested size (0 is ok here).
2631 savepoint_offset must be initialized statically to the size of
2632 the needed memory to store per-savepoint information.
2633 After xxx_init it is changed to be an offset to savepoint storage
2634 area and need not be used by storage engine.
2635 see binlog_hton and binlog_savepoint_set/rollback for an example.
2636 */
2637 uint savepoint_offset;
2638
2639 /* handlerton methods */
2640
2641 close_connection_t close_connection;
2642 kill_connection_t kill_connection;

2841 /* Possible flags of a handlerton (there can be 32 of them) */
2842 #define HTON_NO_FLAGS 0
2843 #define HTON_CLOSE_CURSORS_AT_COMMIT (1 << 0)
2844 #define HTON_ALTER_NOT_SUPPORTED (1 << 1) // Engine does not support alter
2845 #define HTON_CAN_RECREATE (1 << 2) // Delete all is used for truncate
2846 #define HTON_HIDDEN (1 << 3) // Engine does not appear in lists
2847 /*
2848 Bit 4 was occupied by BDB-specific HTON_FLUSH_AFTER_RENAME flag and is no
2849 longer used.
2850 */
2851 #define HTON_NOT_USER_SELECTABLE (1 << 5)
2852 #define HTON_TEMPORARY_NOT_SUPPORTED \
2853 (1 << 6) // Having temporary tables not supported
2854 #define HTON_SUPPORT_LOG_TABLES (1 << 7) // Engine supports log tables
2855 #define HTON_NO_PARTITION (1 << 8) // You can not partition these tables
2856
2857 /*
2858 This flag should be set when deciding that the engine does not allow row based
2859 binary logging (RBL) optimizations.
2860
2861 Currently, setting this flag, means that table's read/write_set will be left
2862 untouched when logging changes to tables in this engine. In practice this
2863 means that the server will not mess around with table->write_set and/or
2864 table->read_set when using RBL and deciding whether to log full or minimal
2865 rows.
2866
2867 It's valuable for instance for virtual tables, eg: Performance Schema which
2868 have no meaning for replication.
2869 */
2870 #define HTON_NO_BINLOG_ROW_OPT (1 << 9)
2871
2872 /**
2873 Engine supports extended keys. The flag allows to
2874 use 'extended key' feature if the engine is able to
2875 do it (has primary key values in the secondary key).
2876 Note that handler flag HA_PRIMARY_KEY_IN_READ_INDEX is
2877 actually partial case of HTON_SUPPORTS_EXTENDED_KEYS.
2878 */
2879
2880 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_EXTENDED_KEYS (1 << 10)
2881
2882 // Engine support foreign key constraint.
2883
2884 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_FOREIGN_KEYS (1 << 11)
2885
2886 /**
2887 Engine supports atomic DDL. That is rollback of transaction for DDL
2888 statement will also rollback all changes in SE, commit of transaction
2889 of DDL statement will make it durable.
2890 */
2891
2892 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_ATOMIC_DDL (1 << 12)
2893
2894 /* Engine supports packed keys. */
2895 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_PACKED_KEYS (1 << 13)
2896
2897 /** Engine is a secondary storage engine. */
2898 #define HTON_IS_SECONDARY_ENGINE (1 << 14)
2899
2900 /** Engine supports secondary storage engines. */
2901 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_SECONDARY_ENGINE (1 << 15)
2902
2903 /** Engine supports table or tablespace encryption . */
2904 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_TABLE_ENCRYPTION (1 << 16)
2905
2906 struct TABLE_STATS {
2907 ulonglong rows_read, rows_changed;
2908 ulonglong rows_changed_x_indexes;
2909 /* Stores enum db_type, but forward declarations cannot be done */
2910 const int engine_type;
2911
2912 289 TABLE_STATS(int engine_type_, ulonglong rows_read_, ulonglong rows_changed_,
2913 ulonglong rows_changed_x_indexes_)
2914 noexcept
2915 289 : rows_read(rows_read_),
2916 289 rows_changed(rows_changed_),
2917 289 rows_changed_x_indexes(rows_changed_x_indexes_),
2918 289 engine_type(engine_type_) {}
2919 };

2921 constexpr const decltype(handlerton::flags) HTON_SUPPORTS_ENGINE_ATTRIBUTE{
2922 1 << 17};
2923
2924 /** Engine supports Generated invisible primary key. */
2925 constexpr const decltype(
2926 handlerton::flags) HTON_SUPPORTS_GENERATED_INVISIBLE_PK{1 << 18};
2927
2928 /**
2929 Set if the storage engine supports 'online' backups. This means that there
2930 exists a way to create a consistent copy of its tables without blocking
2931 updates to them. If so, statements that update such tables will not be
2932 affected by an active LOCK TABLES FOR BACKUP.
2933 */
2934 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_ONLINE_BACKUPS (1 << 19)
2935
2936 /**
2937 Engine supports secondary clustered keys.
2938 */
2939 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_CLUSTERED_KEYS (1 << 20)
2940
2941 /**
2942 Engine supports compressed columns.
2943 */
2944 #define HTON_SUPPORTS_COMPRESSED_COLUMNS (1 << 21)
2945
2946 #ifdef WITH_WSREP
2947 /**
2948 Engine support replication through wsrep-replication provider plugin
2949 */
2950 #define HTON_WSREP_REPLICATION (1 << 22)
2951 #endif /* WITH_WSREP */
2952
2953 26120 inline bool ddl_is_atomic(const handlerton *hton) {
2954 26120 return (hton->flags & HTON_SUPPORTS_ATOMIC_DDL) != 0;
2955 }
2956
2957 /* Bits for handlerton::foreign_keys_flags bitmap. */
2958
2959 /**
2960 Engine supports both unique and non-unique parent keys for
2961 foreign keys which contain full foreign key as its prefix.
2962
2963 Storage engines which support foreign keys but do not have
2964 this flag set are assumed to support only parent keys which
2965 are primary/unique and contain exactly the same columns as
2966 the foreign key, possibly, in different order.
2967 */
2968
2969 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_WITH_PREFIX_PARENT_KEYS = (1 << 0);
2970
2971 /**
2972 Storage engine supports hash keys as supporting keys for foreign
2973 keys. Hash key should contain all foreign key columns and only
2974 them (although in any order).
2975
2976 Storage engines which support foreign keys but do not have this
2977 flag set are assumed to not allow hash keys as supporting keys.
2978 */
2979
2980 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_WITH_SUPPORTING_HASH_KEYS = (1 << 1);
2981
2982 /**
2983 Storage engine supports non-hash keys which have common prefix
2984 with the foreign key as supporting keys for it. If there are
2985 several such keys, one which shares biggest prefix with FK is
2986 chosen.
2987
2988 Storage engines which support foreign keys but do not have this
2989 flag set are assumed to require that supporting key contains full
2990 foreign key as its prefix.
2991 */
2992
2993 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_WITH_ANY_PREFIX_SUPPORTING_KEYS = (1 << 2);
2994
2995 /**
2996 Storage engine does not support using the same key for both parent
2997 and supporting key, but requires the two to be different.
2998 */
2999
3000 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_NEED_DIFFERENT_PARENT_AND_SUPPORTING_KEYS =
3001 (1 << 3);
3002
3003 /**
3004 Engine takes into account hidden part of key (coming from primary key)
3005 when determines if it can serve as parent key for a foreign key.
3006
3007 Implies HTON_FKS_WITH_PREFIX_PARENT_KEYS and is related to
3008 HTON_SUPPORTS_EXTENDED_KEYS.
3009 */
3010
3011 static const uint32 HTON_FKS_WITH_EXTENDED_PARENT_KEYS = (1 << 4);
3012
3013 /**
3014 Maximum possible length of SE-specific suffixes for auto-generated
3015 foreign key names.
3016 */
3017 static const size_t MAX_FK_NAME_SUFFIX_LENGTH = 16;
3018
3019 /**
3020 Suffix for auto-generated foreign key names for tables in SE's which
3021 don't specify own suffix. I.e. for foreign keys on tables in such
3022 SE's generated names follow (table name)FK_NAME_DEFAULT_SUFFIX(FK number)
3023 pattern.
3024 */
3025 static const LEX_CSTRING FK_NAME_DEFAULT_SUFFIX = {STRING_WITH_LEN("_fk_")};

3196 /**
3197 Class describing changes to be done by ALTER TABLE.
3198 Instance of this class is passed to storage engine in order
3199 to determine if this ALTER TABLE can be done using in-place
3200 algorithm. It is also used for executing the ALTER TABLE
3201 using in-place algorithm.
3202 */
3203
3204 class Alter_inplace_info {
3205 public:
3206 /**
3207 Bits to show in detail what operations the storage engine is
3208 to execute.
3209
3210 All these operations are supported as in-place operations by the
3211 SQL layer. This means that operations that by their nature must
3212 be performed by copying the table to a temporary table, will not
3213 have their own flags here (e.g. ALTER TABLE FORCE, ALTER TABLE
3214 ENGINE).
3215
3216 We generally try to specify handler flags only if there are real
3217 changes. But in cases when it is cumbersome to determine if some
3218 attribute has really changed we might choose to set flag
3219 pessimistically, for example, relying on parser output only.
3220 */
3221 typedef ulonglong HA_ALTER_FLAGS;
3222
3223 // Add non-unique, non-primary index
3224 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_INDEX = 1ULL << 0;
3225
3226 // Drop non-unique, non-primary index
3227 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_INDEX = 1ULL << 1;
3228
3229 // Add unique, non-primary index
3230 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_UNIQUE_INDEX = 1ULL << 2;
3231
3232 // Drop unique, non-primary index
3233 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_UNIQUE_INDEX = 1ULL << 3;
3234
3235 // Add primary index
3236 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_PK_INDEX = 1ULL << 4;
3237
3238 // Drop primary index
3239 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_PK_INDEX = 1ULL << 5;
3240
3241 // Add column
3242
3243 // Virtual generated column
3244 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_VIRTUAL_COLUMN = 1ULL << 6;
3245 // Stored base (non-generated) column
3246 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_STORED_BASE_COLUMN = 1ULL << 7;
3247 // Stored generated column
3248 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_STORED_GENERATED_COLUMN = 1ULL << 8;
3249 // Add generic column (convenience constant).
3250 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ADD_COLUMN =
3251 ADD_VIRTUAL_COLUMN | ADD_STORED_BASE_COLUMN | ADD_STORED_GENERATED_COLUMN;
3252
3253 // Drop column
3254 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_VIRTUAL_COLUMN = 1ULL << 9;
3255 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_STORED_COLUMN = 1ULL << 10;
3256 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS DROP_COLUMN =
3257 DROP_VIRTUAL_COLUMN | DROP_STORED_COLUMN;
3258
3259 // Rename column
3260 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_COLUMN_NAME = 1ULL << 11;
3261
3262 // Change column datatype
3263 static const HA_ALTER_FLAGS ALTER_VIRTUAL_COLUMN_TYPE = 1ULL << 12;

3829 /*
3830 The below two are not used (and not handled) in this milestone of this WL
3831 entry because there seems to be no use for them at this stage of
3832 implementation.
3833 */
3834 #define HA_MRR_SINGLE_POINT 1
3835 #define HA_MRR_FIXED_KEY 2
3836
3837 /*
3838 Indicates that RANGE_SEQ_IF::next(&range) doesn't need to fill in the
3839 'range' parameter.
3840 */
3841 #define HA_MRR_NO_ASSOCIATION 4
3842
3843 /*
3844 The MRR user will provide ranges in key order, and MRR implementation
3845 must return rows in key order.
3846 Passing this flag to multi_read_range_init() may cause the
3847 default MRR handler to be used even if HA_MRR_USE_DEFAULT_IMPL
3848 was not specified.
3849 (If the native MRR impl. can not provide SORTED result)
3850 */
3851 #define HA_MRR_SORTED 8
3852
3853 /* MRR implementation doesn't have to retrieve full records */
3854 #define HA_MRR_INDEX_ONLY 16
3855
3856 /*
3857 The passed memory buffer is of maximum possible size, the caller can't
3858 assume larger buffer.
3859 */
3860 #define HA_MRR_LIMITS 32
3861
3862 /*
3863 Flag set <=> default MRR implementation is used
3864 (The choice is made by **_info[_const]() function which may set this

3873 will not have NULL values.
3874 */

3877 /*

3879 produced sorted result if multi_range_read_init() is called with
3880 the HA_MRR_SORTED flag - Else multi_range_read_init(HA_MRR_SORTED)
3881 will revert to use the default MRR implementation.

4049
4050 /**
4051 The handler class is the interface for dynamically loadable
4052 storage engines. Do not add ifdefs and take care when adding or
4053 changing virtual functions to avoid vtable confusion
4054
4055 Functions in this class accept and return table columns data. Two data
4056 representation formats are used:
4057 1. TableRecordFormat - Used to pass [partial] table records to/from
4058 storage engine
4059
4060 2. KeyTupleFormat - used to pass index search tuples (aka "keys") to
4061 storage engine. See opt_range.cc for description of this format.
4062
4063 TableRecordFormat
4064 =================
4065 [Warning: this description is work in progress and may be incomplete]
4066 The table record is stored in a fixed-size buffer:
4067
4068 record: null_bytes, column1_data, column2_data, ...
4069
4070 The offsets of the parts of the buffer are also fixed: every column has
4071 an offset to its column{i}_data, and if it is nullable it also has its own
4072 bit in null_bytes.
4073
4074 The record buffer only includes data about columns that are marked in the
4075 relevant column set (table->read_set and/or table->write_set, depending on
4076 the situation).
4077 <not-sure>It could be that it is required that null bits of non-present
4078 columns are set to 1</not-sure>
4079
4080 VARIOUS EXCEPTIONS AND SPECIAL CASES
4081
4082 If the table has no nullable columns, then null_bytes is still
4083 present, its length is one byte <not-sure> which must be set to 0xFF
4084 at all times. </not-sure>
4085
4086 If the table has columns of type BIT, then certain bits from those columns
4087 may be stored in null_bytes as well. Grep around for Field_bit for
4088 details.
4089
4090 For blob columns (see Field_blob), the record buffer stores length of the
4091 data, following by memory pointer to the blob data. The pointer is owned
4092 by the storage engine and is valid until the next operation.
4093
4094 If a blob column has NULL value, then its length and blob data pointer
4095 must be set to 0.
4096
4097
4098 Overview of main modules of the handler API
4099 ===========================================
4100 The overview below was copied from the storage/partition/ha_partition.h when
4101 support for non-native partitioning was removed.
4102
4103 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4104 MODULE create/delete handler object
4105 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4106 Object create/delete method. Normally called when a table object
4107 exists.
4108
4109 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4110 MODULE meta data changes
4111 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4112 Meta data routines to CREATE, DROP, RENAME table are often used at
4113 ALTER TABLE (update_create_info used from ALTER TABLE and SHOW ..).
4114
4115 Methods:
4116 delete_table()
4117 rename_table()
4118 create()
4119 update_create_info()
4120
4121 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4122 MODULE open/close object
4123 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4124 Open and close handler object to ensure all underlying files and
4125 objects allocated and deallocated for query handling is handled
4126 properly.
4127
4128 A handler object is opened as part of its initialisation and before
4129 being used for normal queries (not before meta-data changes always.
4130 If the object was opened it will also be closed before being deleted.
4131
4132 Methods:
4133 open()
4134 close()
4135
4136 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4137 MODULE start/end statement
4138 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4139 This module contains methods that are used to understand start/end of
4140 statements, transaction boundaries, and aid for proper concurrency
4141 control.
4142
4143 Methods:
4144 store_lock()
4145 external_lock()
4146 start_stmt()
4147 lock_count()
4148 unlock_row()
4149 was_semi_consistent_read()
4150 try_semi_consistent_read()
4151
4152 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4153 MODULE change record
4154 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4155 This part of the handler interface is used to change the records
4156 after INSERT, DELETE, UPDATE, REPLACE method calls but also other
4157 special meta-data operations as ALTER TABLE, LOAD DATA, TRUNCATE.
4158
4159 These methods are used for insert (write_row), update (update_row)
4160 and delete (delete_row). All methods to change data always work on
4161 one row at a time. update_row and delete_row also contains the old
4162 row.
4163 delete_all_rows will delete all rows in the table in one call as a
4164 special optimization for DELETE from table;
4165
4166 Bulk inserts are supported if all underlying handlers support it.
4167 start_bulk_insert and end_bulk_insert is called before and after a
4168 number of calls to write_row.
4169
4170 Methods:
4171 write_row()
4172 update_row()
4173 delete_row()
4174 delete_all_rows()
4175 start_bulk_insert()
4176 end_bulk_insert()
4177
4178 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4179 MODULE full table scan
4180 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4181 This module is used for the most basic access method for any table
4182 handler. This is to fetch all data through a full table scan. No
4183 indexes are needed to implement this part.
4184 It contains one method to start the scan (rnd_init) that can also be
4185 called multiple times (typical in a nested loop join). Then proceeding
4186 to the next record (rnd_next) and closing the scan (rnd_end).
4187 To remember a record for later access there is a method (position)
4188 and there is a method used to retrieve the record based on the stored
4189 position.
4190 The position can be a file position, a primary key, a ROWID dependent
4191 on the handler below.
4192
4193 All functions that retrieve records and are callable through the
4194 handler interface must indicate whether a record is present after the call
4195 or not. Record found is indicated by returning 0 and setting table status
4196 to "has row". Record not found is indicated by returning a non-zero value
4197 and setting table status to "no row".
4198 @see TABLE::set_found_row() and TABLE::set_no_row().
4199 By enforcing these rules in the handler interface, storage handler functions
4200 need not set any status in struct TABLE. These notes also apply to module
4201 index scan, documented below.
4202
4203 Methods:
4204
4205 rnd_init()
4206 rnd_end()
4207 rnd_next()
4208 rnd_pos()
4209 rnd_pos_by_record()
4210 position()
4211
4212 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4213 MODULE index scan
4214 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4215 This part of the handler interface is used to perform access through
4216 indexes. The interface is defined as a scan interface but the handler
4217 can also use key lookup if the index is a unique index or a primary
4218 key index.
4219 Index scans are mostly useful for SELECT queries but are an important
4220 part also of UPDATE, DELETE, REPLACE and CREATE TABLE table AS SELECT
4221 and so forth.
4222 Naturally an index is needed for an index scan and indexes can either
4223 be ordered, hash based. Some ordered indexes can return data in order
4224 but not necessarily all of them.
4225 There are many flags that define the behavior of indexes in the
4226 various handlers. These methods are found in the optimizer module.
4227
4228 index_read is called to start a scan of an index. The find_flag defines
4229 the semantics of the scan. These flags are defined in
4230 include/my_base.h
4231 index_read_idx is the same but also initializes index before calling doing
4232 the same thing as index_read. Thus it is similar to index_init followed
4233 by index_read. This is also how we implement it.
4234
4235 index_read/index_read_idx does also return the first row. Thus for
4236 key lookups, the index_read will be the only call to the handler in
4237 the index scan.
4238
4239 index_init initializes an index before using it and index_end does
4240 any end processing needed.
4241
4242 Methods:
4243 index_read_map()
4244 index_init()
4245 index_end()
4246 index_read_idx_map()
4247 index_next()
4248 index_prev()
4249 index_first()
4250 index_last()
4251 index_next_same()
4252 index_read_last_map()
4253 read_range_first()
4254 read_range_next()
4255
4256 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4257 MODULE information calls
4258 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4259 This calls are used to inform the handler of specifics of the ongoing
4260 scans and other actions. Most of these are used for optimisation
4261 purposes.
4262
4263 Methods:
4264 info()
4265 get_dynamic_partition_info
4266 extra()
4267 extra_opt()
4268 reset()
4269
4270 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4271 MODULE optimizer support
4272 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4273 NOTE:
4274 One important part of the public handler interface that is not depicted in
4275 the methods is the attribute records which is defined in the base class.
4276 This is looked upon directly and is set by calling info(HA_STATUS_INFO) ?
4277
4278 Methods:
4279 min_rows_for_estimate()
4280 get_biggest_used_partition()
4281 scan_time()
4282 read_time()
4283 records_in_range()
4284 estimate_rows_upper_bound()
4285 records()
4286
4287 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4288 MODULE print messages
4289 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4290 This module contains various methods that returns text messages for
4291 table types, index type and error messages.
4292
4293 Methods:
4294 table_type()
4295 get_row_type()
4296 print_error()
4297 get_error_message()
4298
4299 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4300 MODULE handler characteristics
4301 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4302 This module contains a number of methods defining limitations and
4303 characteristics of the handler (see also documentation regarding the
4304 individual flags).
4305
4306 Methods:
4307 table_flags()
4308 index_flags()
4309 min_of_the_max_uint()
4310 max_supported_record_length()
4311 max_supported_keys()
4312 max_supported_key_parts()
4313 max_supported_key_length()
4314 max_supported_key_part_length()
4315 low_byte_first()
4316 extra_rec_buf_length()
4317 min_record_length(uint options)
4318 primary_key_is_clustered()
4319 ha_key_alg get_default_index_algorithm()
4320 is_index_algorithm_supported()
4321
4322 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4323 MODULE compare records
4324 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4325 cmp_ref checks if two references are the same. For most handlers this is
4326 a simple memcmp of the reference. However some handlers use primary key
4327 as reference and this can be the same even if memcmp says they are
4328 different. This is due to character sets and end spaces and so forth.
4329
4330 Methods:
4331 cmp_ref()
4332
4333 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4334 MODULE auto increment
4335 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4336 This module is used to handle the support of auto increments.
4337
4338 This variable in the handler is used as part of the handler interface
4339 It is maintained by the parent handler object and should not be
4340 touched by child handler objects (see handler.cc for its use).
4341
4342 Methods:

4344 release_auto_increment()
4345
4346 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4347 MODULE initialize handler for HANDLER call
4348 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4349 This method is a special InnoDB method called before a HANDLER query.
4350
4351 Methods:

4358
4359 Methods:

4369
4370 Methods:

4379 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4380 Methods:

4400 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4401 Enable/Disable Indexes are only supported by HEAP and MyISAM.
4402
4403 Methods:

4416 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4417 MODULE partitioning specific handler API
4418 -------------------------------------------------------------------------
4419 Methods:
4420 get_partition_handler()
4421 */

5076 /**
5077 Cost estimate for doing a number of non-sequentially accesses
5078 against the storage engine. Such accesses can be either number
5079 of rows to read, or number of disk pages to access.
5080 Each handler implementation is free to interpret that as best
5081 suited, depending on what is the dominating cost for that
5082 storage engine.
5083
5084 This method is mainly provided as a temporary workaround for
5085 bug#33317872, where we fix problems caused by calling
5086 Cost_model::page_read_cost() directly from the optimizer.
5087 That should be avoided, as it introduced assumption about all
5088 storage engines being disk-page based, and having a 'page' cost.
5089 Furthermore, this page cost was even compared against read_cost(),
5090 which was computed with an entirely different algorithm, and thus
5091 could not be compared.
5092
5093 The default implementation still call Cost_model::page_read_cost(),
5094 thus behaving just as before. However, handler implementation may
5095 override it to call handler::read_cost() instead(), which probably
5096 will be more correct. (If a page_read_cost should be included
5097 in the cost estimate, that should preferable be done inside
5098 each read_cost() implementation)
5099
5100 Longer term we should consider to remove all page_read_cost()
5101 usage from the optimizer itself, making this method obsolete.
5102
5103 @param index the index number
5104 @param reads the number of accesses being made
5105
5106 @returns the estimated cost
5107 */
5108 virtual double page_read_cost(uint index, double reads);
5109
5110 /**
5111 Provide an upper cost-limit of doing a specified number of
5112 seek-and-read key lookups. This need to be comparable and
5113 calculated with the same 'metric' as page_read_cost.
5114
5115 @param reads the number of rows read in the 'worst' case.
5116
5117 @returns the estimated cost
5118 */
5119 virtual double worst_seek_times(double reads);

5714 /**
5715 Normally, when running UPDATE or DELETE queries, we need to wait for other
5716 transactions to release their locks on a given row before we can read it and
5717 potentially update it. However, in READ UNCOMMITTED and READ COMMITTED, we
5718 can ignore these locks if we don't intend to modify the row (e.g., because
5719 it failed a WHERE). This is signaled through enabling “semi-consistent
5720 read”, by calling try_semi_consistent_read(true) (and then setting it back
5721 to false after finishing the query).
5722
5723 If semi-consistent read is enabled, and we are in READ UNCOMMITTED or READ
5724 COMMITTED, the storage engine is permitted to return rows that are locked
5725 and thus un-updatable. If the optimizer doesn't want the row, e.g., because
5726 it got filtered out, it can call unlock_row() as usual. However, if it
5727 intends to update the row, it needs to call was_semi_consistent_read()
5728 before doing so. If was_semi_consistent_read() returns false, the row was
5729 never locked to begin with and can be updated as usual. However, if it
5730 returns 1, it was read optimistically, must be discarded (ie., do not try to
5731 update the row) and must be re-read with locking enabled. The next read call
5732 after was_semi_consistent_read() will automatically re-read the same row,
5733 this time with locking enabled.
5734
5735 Thus, typical use in an UPDATE scenario would look like this:
5736
5737 file->try_semi_consistent_read(true);
5738 file->ha_rnd_init(true);
5739 while (file->ha_rnd_next(table->record[0]) == 0) {
5740 if (row is filtered...) {
5741 file->unlock_row();
5742 continue;
5743 }
5744 if (file->was_semi_consistent_read()) {
5745 // Discard the row; next ha_rnd_next() will read it again with
5746 // locking.
5747 continue;
5748 }
5749 // Process row here.
5750 }
5751 file->ha_rnd_end();
5752 file->try_semi_consistent_read(false);
5753
5754 If the transaction isolation level is REPEATABLE READ or SERIALIZABLE,
5755 enabling this flag has no effect.
5756 */
5757 861414 virtual bool was_semi_consistent_read() { return false; }
5758 /**
5759 Tell the engine whether it should avoid unnecessary lock waits.
5760 If yes, in an UPDATE or DELETE, if the row under the cursor was locked
5761 by another transaction, the engine may try an optimistic read of
5762 the last committed row value under the cursor.
5763 */
5764 24641 virtual void try_semi_consistent_read(bool) {}

5922 We return number of partitions we will lock multiplied with number of
5923 locks needed by each partition. Assists the above functions in allocating
5924 sufficient space for lock structures.

5932
5933 /**
5934 Is not invoked for non-transactional temporary tables.
5935
5936 @note store_lock() can return more than one lock if the table is MERGE
5937 or partitioned.
5938
5939 @note that one can NOT rely on table->in_use in store_lock(). It may
5940 refer to a different thread if called from mysql_lock_abort_for_thread().
5941
5942 @note If the table is MERGE, store_lock() can return less locks
5943 than lock_count() claimed. This can happen when the MERGE children
5944 are not attached when this is called from another thread.
5945
5946 The idea with handler::store_lock() is the following:
5947
5948 The statement decided which locks we should need for the table
5949 for updates/deletes/inserts we get WRITE locks, for SELECT... we get
5950 read locks.
5951
5952 Before adding the lock into the table lock handler (see thr_lock.c)
5953 mysqld calls store lock with the requested locks. Store lock can now
5954 modify a write lock to a read lock (or some other lock), ignore the
5955 lock (if we don't want to use MySQL table locks at all) or add locks
5956 for many tables (like we do when we are using a MERGE handler).
5957
5958 In some exceptional cases MySQL may send a request for a TL_IGNORE;
5959 This means that we are requesting the same lock as last time and this
5960 should also be ignored.
5961
5962 Called from lock.cc by get_lock_data().
5963 */

6096
6097 /* On-line/in-place/instant ALTER TABLE interface. */
6098
6099 /*
6100 Here is an outline of on-line/in-place ALTER TABLE execution through
6101 this interface.
6102
6103 Phase 1 : Initialization
6104 ========================
6105 During this phase we determine which algorithm should be used
6106 for execution of ALTER TABLE and what level concurrency it will
6107 require.
6108
6109 *) This phase starts by opening the table and preparing description
6110 of the new version of the table.
6111 *) Then we check if it is impossible even in theory to carry out
6112 this ALTER TABLE using the in-place/instant algorithm. For example,
6113 because we need to change storage engine or the user has explicitly
6114 requested usage of the "copy" algorithm.
6115 *) If in-place/instant ALTER TABLE is theoretically possible, we continue
6116 by compiling differences between old and new versions of the table
6117 in the form of HA_ALTER_FLAGS bitmap. We also build a few
6118 auxiliary structures describing requested changes and store
6119 all these data in the Alter_inplace_info object.
6120 *) Then the handler::check_if_supported_inplace_alter() method is called
6121 in order to find if the storage engine can carry out changes requested
6122 by this ALTER TABLE using the in-place or instant algorithm.
6123 To determine this, the engine can rely on data in HA_ALTER_FLAGS/
6124 Alter_inplace_info passed to it as well as on its own checks.
6125 If the in-place algorithm can be used for this ALTER TABLE, the level
6126 of required concurrency for its execution is also returned.
6127 If any errors occur during the handler call, ALTER TABLE is aborted
6128 and no further handler functions are called.
6129 Note that in cases when there is difference between in-place and
6130 instant algorithm and user explicitly asked for usage of in-place
6131 algorithm storage engine MUST return one of values corresponding
6132 to in-place algorithm and not HA_ALTER_INPLACE_INSTANT from this
6133 method.
6134 *) Locking requirements of the in-place algorithm are compared to any
6135 concurrency requirements specified by user. If there is a conflict
6136 between them, we either switch to the copy algorithm or emit an error.
6137
6138 Phase 2 : Execution
6139 ===================
6140
6141 In this phase the operations are executed.
6142
6143 *) As the first step, we acquire a lock corresponding to the concurrency
6144 level which was returned by handler::check_if_supported_inplace_alter()
6145 and requested by the user. This lock is held for most of the
6146 duration of in-place ALTER (if HA_ALTER_INPLACE_SHARED_LOCK_AFTER_PREPARE
6147 or HA_ALTER_INPLACE_NO_LOCK_AFTER_PREPARE were returned we acquire an
6148 exclusive lock for duration of the next step only).
6149 For HA_ALTER_INPLACE_INSTANT we keep shared upgradable metadata lock
6150 which was acquired at table open time.
6151 *) After that we call handler::ha_prepare_inplace_alter_table() to give the
6152 storage engine a chance to update its internal structures with a higher
6153 lock level than the one that will be used for the main step of algorithm.
6154 After that we downgrade the lock if it is necessary.
6155 This step should be no-op for instant algorithm.
6156 *) After that, the main step of this phase and algorithm is executed.
6157 We call the handler::ha_inplace_alter_table() method, which carries out
6158 the changes requested by ALTER TABLE but does not makes them visible to
6159 other connections yet.
6160 This step should be no-op for instant algorithm as well.
6161 *) We ensure that no other connection uses the table by upgrading our
6162 lock on it to exclusive.
6163 *) a) If the previous step succeeds,
6164 handler::ha_commit_inplace_alter_table() is called to allow the storage
6165 engine to do any final updates to its structures, to make all earlier
6166 changes durable and visible to other connections.
6167 For instant algorithm this is the step during which SE changes are done.
6168 Engines that support atomic DDL only prepare for the commit during this
6169 step but do not finalize it. Real commit happens later when the whole
6170 statement is committed. Also in some situations statement might be rolled
6171 back after call to commit_inplace_alter_table() for such storage engines.
6172 In the latter special case SE might require call to
6173 handlerton::dict_cache_reset() in order to invalidate its internal table
6174 definition cache after rollback.
6175 b) If we have failed to upgrade lock or any errors have occurred during
6176 the handler functions calls (including commit), we call
6177 handler::ha_commit_inplace_alter_table() to rollback all changes which
6178 were done during previous steps.
6179
6180 All the above calls to SE are provided with dd::Table objects describing old
6181 and new version of table being altered. Engines which support atomic DDL are
6182 allowed to adjust object corresponding to the new version. During phase 3
6183 these changes are saved to the data-dictionary.
6184
6185
6186 Phase 3 : Final
6187 ===============
6188
6189 In this phase we:
6190
6191 a) For engines which don't support atomic DDL:
6192
6193 *) Update the SQL-layer data-dictionary by replacing description of old
6194 version of the table with its new version. This change is immediately
6195 committed.
6196 *) Inform the storage engine about this change by calling the
6197 handler::ha_notify_table_changed() method.
6198 *) Process the RENAME clause by calling handler::ha_rename_table() and
6199 updating the data-dictionary accordingly. Again this change is
6200 immediately committed.
6201 *) Destroy the Alter_inplace_info and handler_ctx objects.
6202
6203 b) For engines which support atomic DDL:
6204
6205 *) Update the SQL-layer data-dictionary by replacing description of old
6206 version of the table with its new version.
6207 *) Process the RENAME clause by calling handler::ha_rename_table() and
6208 updating the data-dictionary accordingly.
6209 *) Commit the statement/transaction.
6210 *) Finalize atomic DDL operation by calling handlerton::post_ddl() hook
6211 for the storage engine.
6212 *) Additionally inform the storage engine about completion of ALTER TABLE
6213 for the table by calling the handler::ha_notify_table_changed()
6214 method.
6215 *) Destroy the Alter_inplace_info and handler_ctx objects.
6216 */
6217
6218 /**
6219 Check if a storage engine supports a particular alter table in-place
6220
6221 @param altered_table TABLE object for new version of table.
6222 @param ha_alter_info Structure describing changes to be done
6223 by ALTER TABLE and holding data used
6224 during in-place alter.
6225
6226 @retval HA_ALTER_ERROR Unexpected error.

6236 reads/writes allowed. However, prepare phase requires X lock.
6237 @retval HA_ALTER_INPLACE_NO_LOCK Supported, concurrent

6239 @retval HA_ALTER_INPLACE_INSTANT Instant algorithm is supported.

6673 /**
6674 Is not invoked for non-transactional temporary tables.
6675
6676 Tells the storage engine that we intend to read or write data
6677 from the table. This call is prefixed with a call to handler::store_lock()
6678 and is invoked only for those handler instances that stored the lock.
6679
6680 Calls to @c rnd_init / @c index_init are prefixed with this call. When table
6681 IO is complete, we call @code external_lock(F_UNLCK) @endcode.
6682 A storage engine writer should expect that each call to
6683 @code ::external_lock(F_[RD|WR]LOCK @endcode is followed by a call to
6684 @code ::external_lock(F_UNLCK) @endcode. If it is not, it is a bug in MySQL.
6685
6686 The name and signature originate from the first implementation
6687 in MyISAM, which would call @c fcntl to set/clear an advisory
6688 lock on the data file in this method.
6689
6690 Originally this method was used to set locks on file level to enable
6691 several MySQL Servers to work on the same data. For transactional
6692 engines it has been "abused" to also mean start and end of statements
6693 to enable proper rollback of statements and transactions. When LOCK
6694 TABLES has been issued the start_stmt method takes over the role of
6695 indicating start of statement but in this case there is no end of
6696 statement indicator(?).
6697
6698 Called from lock.cc by lock_external() and unlock_external(). Also called
6699 from sql_table.cc by copy_data_between_tables().
6700
6701 @param thd the current thread
6702 @param lock_type F_RDLCK, F_WRLCK, F_UNLCK
6703
6704 @return non-0 in case of failure, 0 in case of success.
6705 When lock_type is F_UNLCK, the return value is ignored.
6706 */
6707 1401258 virtual int external_lock(THD *thd [[maybe_unused]],
6708 int lock_type [[maybe_unused]]) {
6709 1401258 return 0;
6710 }

7456 /**
7457 Stage of the recovery process where information is collected from the
7458 storage engines (SE), merged with information from the transaction
7459 coordinator (TC) and transactions states are determined and enforced.
7460
7461 Implemented heuristics is as follows:
7462
7463 1. The `commit_list` parameter contains the set of internally coordinated
7464 transactions that the TC ensures were marked as committed.
7465
7466 2. The `xa_state_list` parameter contains the list of externally
7467 coordinated transactions and their states, as recorded by the TC.
7468
7469 3. For each SE:
7470 a. Collect list of transactions found in `PREPARED_IN_TC` state in the
7471 SE and merge it with the information collected from the TC, in
7472 `xa_state_list`.
7473 b. Retrieve the list of transactions found in prepared state in the
7474 SE.
7475
7476 c. For each internally coordinated transactions found in prepared
7477 state:
7478 1. If the transaction is found in `commit_list`, commit it.
7479 2. If the transaction is NOT found in `commit_list` but
7480 `tc_heuristic_recover = TC_HEURISTIC_RECOVER_COMMIT`, commit it.
7481 3. Otherwise, roll it back.
7482
7483 d. For each externally coordinated transactions found in prepared
7484 state:
7485 1. If the transaction isn't found in `xa_state_list`, roll it back.
7486 2. If the transaction is found in `xa_state_list` in `COMMITTED`
7487 state, commit it.
7488 3. If the transaction is found in `xa_state_list` in `ROLLEDBACK`
7489 state, roll it back.
7490 4. If the transaction is found in `xa_state_list` in `PREPARED`
7491 state, ensure that the transaction state in the SE is
7492 `PREPARED_IN_TC`.
7493
7494 @param commit_list Set of XIDs of internally coordinated transactions
7495 found as been committed in the transaction coordinator
7496 state.
7497 @param xa_state_list Map between XIDs and states of externally
7498 coordinated transactions as found in the internal
7499 transaction coordinator state.
7500
7501 @return 0 if recovery was successfull, non-zero otherwise.
7502 */
7503 int ha_recover(Xid_commit_list *commit_list = nullptr,
7504 Xa_state_list *xa_state_list = nullptr);
7505
7506 /**
7507 Perform SE-specific cleanup after recovery of transactions.
7508
7509 @note SE supporting atomic DDL can use this method to perform
7510 post-DDL actions for DDL statements which were committed
7511 or rolled back during recovery stage.
7512 */
7513 void ha_post_recover();
